description: From Middle English forslowen, forslewen (“to neglect”), from Old English forslāwian, forslǣwan (“to be slow, unwilling, delay, put off”), equivalent to for- +‎ slow.

verbs.description: forslow (third-person singular simple present forslows, present participle forslowing, simple past and past participle forslowed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To be dilatory about; put off; postpone; neglect; omit.
(transitive, obsolete) To delay; hinder; impede; obstruct.
examples: The wond'ring Nereids, though they rais'd no storm, / Foreslow'd her passage, to behold her form.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To be slow or dilatory; loiter.
